docs.lead_paragraph: Staking out the political center, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut warned today that nominating Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, as the Democrat to face President Bush in 2004 would be ''a ticket to nowhere.'' During an appearance here at the National Press Club, Mr. Lieberman was asked about the increased attention in the news to Dr. Dean. Mr. Lieberman said: ''A candidate who was opposed to the war against Saddam, who has called for the repeal of all of the Bush tax cuts -- which would result in an increase in taxes on the middle class -- I believe will not offer the kind of leadership America needs to meet the challenges that we face today.''
docs.abstract: Sen Joseph I Lieberman, seeking Democratic presidential nomination, warns that nominating Howard Dean to face Pres Bush in 2004 would lead Democratic Party into political wilderness for long time to come, appearance at National Press Club; is staking out political center, amplifying concern expressed last week by Democratic Leadership Council, centrist organization he once led; his blunt criticism of fellow Democrat seen as tacit admission both that Dean has emerged as unofficial front-runner and that he, Lieberman, is struggling to capture popular imagination; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Medco Health Solutions unit of Merck & Company said yesterday that a federal judge in White Plains gave preliminary approval to a $42.5 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit. The plaintiffs had claimed that they did not get the maximum savings they had been promised through the Medco unit. Merck and Medco did not admit to any liability as part of the agreement, which requires changes in the way Medco notifies subscribers of coverage.

headline.main: JUDGE APPROVES SETTLEMENT OF DRUG INSURANCE SUIT

docs.abstract: Merck & Co's Medco Health Solutions unit says federal judge gave premilinary approval to $42.5 million settlement of class-action suit charging plaintiffs did not get maximum savings they had been promised through Medco; accord requires changes in way Medco notifies subscribers of coverage (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government should require all health insurance policies to pay for vaccines, should reimburse insurers for the costs and should subsidize vaccines for uninsured people, an expert panel from the National Academy of Sciences said today. The proposals for a sweeping overhaul of vaccine policy are a response to recent shortages in the supply of some vaccines and a steady decline in the number of companies producing vaccines.

headline.main: PANEL URGES U.S. TO BROADEN ROLE IN VACCINATIONS

docs.abstract: National Academy of Sciences panel says federal government should require all health insurance policies to pay for vaccines, should reimburse insurers for costs and should subsidize vaccines for uninsured people; cites recent shortages in supply of some vaccines and steady decline in number of companies producing vaccines; major purpose of sweeping overhaul of vaccine policy is to guarantee that everyone has access to growing number of new and expensive but effective vaccines; panel also hopes to stimulate and sustain investment in new vaccines, by assuring that manufacturers can achieve adequate return on their investments; proposal for 'insurance mandate' and subsidies would increase federal spending on vaccines by unspecified amount; it is subject to approval by Congress; special report may prompt action on Capitol Hill; photo; map; chart (M)
docs.snippet: The federal government should require all health insurance policies to pay for vaccines, should reimburse insurers for the costs and should subsidize vaccines for uninsured people, an expert panel from the National Academy of Sciences said today.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Higher Mortgage Rates Could Be Drag on Economy A month after the Federal Reserve reduced its overnight lending rate to just 1 percent, home mortgage rates have shot up and abruptly stalled plans by thousands of homeowners to refinance their houses at lower rates. If the higher rates persist, they will make it more expensive for people to buy houses or to borrow money against their houses for renovations, furniture and even cars. That would dampen a main source of consumer demand over the last two years. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Health Net Inc., a leading provider of health plans for the United States military, said yesterday that quarterly profit climbed, beating Wall Street forecasts, as it raised premiums to stay ahead of soaring medical costs. Health Net's results are among the last in the H.M.O. reporting season. With the notable exception of Cigna's net loss last week, all the major health insurance companies posted profit gains, many by double digits. Health Net is one of a handful of companies that run Tricare, the health plan for troops and their families.
docs.abstract: Health Net Inc, provider of health plans for United States military, reports quarterly profit climbed, beating analysts' forecasts (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 First Peacekeepers Arrive In Bleak Liberian Capital The first planeloads of West African peacekeepers arrived in Monrovia, bringing hope that months of fighting might soon end. With President Bush still undecided about deploying the American forces positioned offshore in three warships, the Nigerian troops did not venture beyond the airport. They are the first of an expected force of 3,250 West African soldiers. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER THE BALL Gilded Age Secrets, Boardroom Betrayals and the Party That Ignited the Great Wall Street Scandal of 1905 By Patricia Beard 402 pages. Illustrated. HarperCollins. $25.95. In her colorful new book about fiscal scandal, Patricia Beard writes: ''As excess, greed, and financial chicanery oozed out, it became evident that the saga was driven by huge sums of money. The stakes were getting higher all the time, and it seemed that reputations would be ruined, legal actions taken, and the sight of the mighty being led off to prison might give the drama an explosive last act.'' The pertinent events are almost a century old, but they certainly sound familiar.

headline.main: When Financial Scandals Were More Fun

docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews book After the Ball: Gilded Age Secrets, Boardroom Betrayals and the Party That Ignited the Great Wall Street Scandal of 1905 by Patricia Beard; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A proposal to help elderly people get discounts on prescription drugs, a relatively minor part of legislation adding drug benefits to Medicare, has become a major source of disagreement, lawmakers and administration officials say. For two years, President Bush has said he wants to give immediate help to the elderly by providing them with drug discount cards endorsed by the federal government. But the administration is now complaining about many provisions of bills passed by both houses of Congress to authorize such cards.

headline.main: MEDICARE DRUG BILL HELD UP BY DISPUTE ON DISCOUNT CARDS

docs.abstract: Proposal to help elderly people get discounts on prescription drugs, relatively minor part of legislation adding drug benefits to Medicare, has become major source of disagreement; Pres Bush first proposed giving immediate help to elderly with drug discount cards endorsed by federal government in July 2001, but administration is objecting to major features of drug discount cards planned by House and Senate; it opposes specifying amount of discount, as contained in Senate bill, and House bill's requirement that drug card sponsors provide counseling and other assistance to people taking multiple drugs for chronic diseases; discount cards are important for political reasons as well; they would provide tangible aid to elderly voters before 2004 elections; lawmakers had hoped agreement on drug discount cards would generate momentum as negotiators turn to bigger, more contentious issues (M)
docs.snippet: A proposal to help elderly people get discounts on prescription drugs, a relatively minor part of legislation adding drug benefits to Medicare, has become a major source of disagreement, lawmakers and administration officials say.    For two years,...

docs.lead_paragraph: IGNORE the razor wire twisted outside the windows, and the school building at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility feels like most other academic institutions. Classrooms are filled with blackboards, freestanding globes, desk-and-chair combinations. Inspirational messages line the walls: If you don't get it, try again! Some people have to learn the hard way! Never settle for less than your best! But here, 30 miles up the Hudson from New York City, students don't linger after class. They are herded back to their cells the minute the clock hits 8:30. On this night, Rosemarie Murray's ''Written English and Literary Studies I'' class is discussing the plays read over the semester: ''Oedipus,'' ''Hamlet,'' ''Othello'' and ''A Doll's House.'' Last week they had been asked to answer essay questions, and Dr. Murray hands back their responses.
docs.abstract: Sentiment against higher education in prison grows as states squeeze budgets of public universities and many question value of humanities education for inmates who may never be released; five New York State prisons have degree-granting programs and some prisoners see those programs as break from tedium of prison life or as ticket to eventual life outside prison walls; profiles of Rosemarie Murray, who teaches literature to inmates, and two prisoner-students Juan Roldan and Sean Pico; photos (special section, Education Life) (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: RARELY have the limits of economics been more clearly delineated than in last week's reports of a proposed futures market for terrorism. The Pentagon has been trying to find ways to know the unknowable. Where are terrorists likely to attack? When, and how? Not surprisingly for an administration with such professed trust in the power of markets, the experts came up with the notion of an open exchange.

headline.main: Economics Can't Solve Everything, Can It?

docs.abstract: Daniel Skst column says federal government should make Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac operate by market rules, without guarantee that federal government will not let them fail; cartoon (M)
